title: 109_s660
content: The "Lumbee Recognition Act" is the short title of this Act. The preamble of the Act of June 7, 1956 is amended by making specific changes to the wording. The Lumbee Indians of North Carolina, recognized by the state since 1885 and by Congress in 1956, are seeking full Federal recognition and the benefits that come with it. Federal recognition is extended to the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina, allowing them to receive benefits and services available to other Indian tribes. Any group of Indians in specific counties in North Carolina not enrolled in the Lumbee Tribe may petition for acknowledgment of tribal existence. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina and its members are eligible for services and benefits provided to federally recognized Indian tribes. Members residing in specific counties are considered to be on or near a reservation. The Secretary of the Interior and Health and Human Services will determine needs and budget for services in consultation with the tribe. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina is eligible for federal services based on their tribal roll, which defines their service population. The Secretaries of the Interior and Health and Human Services will determine needs and budget for services in consultation with the tribe. Verification of membership criteria will be completed within a year of the enactment of this section. The Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina seeks to convey fee land to the United States for trust purposes within Robeson County, North Carolina. The Secretary of the Interior will treat the land as on-reservation trust acquisitions. The State of North Carolina has jurisdiction over criminal offenses and civil actions on land owned by the Lumbee Tribe of North Carolina. The Secretary of the Interior can accept jurisdiction transfers from the state after consulting with the Attorney General. This section does not affect the Indian Child Welfare Act. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out this Act.
